channel.title: NYT > Business
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Anderson Cooper Is Leaving ’60 Minutes’
item.description: Mr. Cooper said in a statement that he was leaving as a correspondent for the show to focus on his CNN program and spend more time with his children.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Adrienne Grunwald for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anderson Cooper has been a correspondent on the CBS newsmagazine for almost 20 years.

item.title: Vaccine Makers Curtail Research and Cut Jobs
item.description: Federal policies under Robert F. Kennedy Jr. that are hostile to vaccines have “sent a chill through the entire industry,” one scientist said.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:credit: Brian Snyder/Reuters
item.media:description: Moderna says it plans to pull back on late-stage studies of some of its experimental vaccines.

item.title: Should Drug Companies Be Advertising to Consumers?
item.description: Aging means “becoming a target” of the industry, one expert said. After decades of debate, politicians of all stripes are proposing bans.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span
item.media:credit: Luisa Jung

item.title: How the H-1B Visa Debate Is Driving a Wave of Racism Against South Asians
item.description: A dispute over the impact of H-1B visas on U.S. workers has been overshadowed by racist rhetoric, with troubling echoes of the great replacement conspiracy theory.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Frisco, Texas, one-third of the population is of Asian heritage.

item.title: The Quiet Architect of Trump’s Global Trade War
item.description: Jamieson Greer, a low-key lawyer from a working-class background, is rewriting the rules of the global economy at the president’s behest.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jamieson Greer, the U.S. trade representative, has quietly navigated the demands of an unpredictable president.

item.title: How a Trump Tax Break Rescued Horse Racing
item.description: Owners spent nearly $1.5 billion last year on racehorses, a big increase over 2024. A new tax provision allows them to immediately deduct the full cost of the purchase.
item.dc:creator: Joe Drape
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry for The New York Times

item.title: Diplomatic Feud With China Weighs on Japan’s Economy
item.description: A standoff over the security of Taiwan has led to a steep decline in the number of Chinese visitors to Japan, which is heavily dependent on the tourists.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis
item.media:credit: Greg Baker/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Chinese tour group in Tokyo last year. A decline in visitors has followed remarks by the Japanese prime minister suggesting Japan would come to Taiwan’s defense in the event of a Chinese invasion.

item.title: Warner Bros. Is Said to Consider Reopening Talks With Paramount
item.description: Warner Bros. Discovery had agreed to sell itself to Netflix, but its contract allows it to pursue offers that may lead to a superior deal.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Aleksey Kondratyev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Warner Bros. Discovery has until Feb. 25 to respond to Paramount’s latest proposal.

item.title: Trump Administration Ends Credit for Start-Stop Feature in Cars
item.description: Manufacturers will no longer get a credit toward vehicle emissions standards by installing engines that automatically stop at red lights.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Stella Kalinina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Complaints to the U.S. Department of Transportation about the start-stop feature peaked in 2022 and fell almost in half by 2024.

item.title: Like Trump, U.S. Embassies Are Raising Cash for Lavish July Fourth Parties
item.description: Some of Washington’s diplomatic outposts in Asia are raising millions for events to mark the 250th independence anniversary. One ambassador offered to sing and dance.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, River Akira Davis and Kenneth P. Vogel
item.media:credit: Heather Diehl/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Washington Monument illuminated on New Year’s Eve. In December, President Trump announced a campaign to organize celebrations of America’s 250th birthday.

item.title: ‘Wuthering Heights’ Gallops Toward $82 Million in Global Ticket Sales
item.description: Warner Bros. spent an estimated $80 million on the R-rated romance, directed by Emerald Fennell, not including hefty marketing costs.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.media:credit: Warner Bros. Pictures
item.media:description: Margot Robbie and Jacob Elordi in “Wuthering Heights.” The director, Emerald Fennell, and Ms. Robbie, a co-producer, went with Warner Bros. because it promised a wide theatrical release.

item.title: Will 2026 Be the Year of the ‘Soonicorn’?
item.description: As venture capital funding pours into start-ups large and small, more firms are pitching themselves as the next big thing.
item.dc:creator: Lora Kelley
item.media:credit: Melanie Lambrick

item.title: What C.E.O.s Are Worried About
item.description: Fractured politics, disruptive technologies and a distrust in institutions are making it harder to focus on the traditional tasks of growing sales and profits.
item.dc:creator: Jordyn Holman
item.category: Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America
item.media:credit: Pete Ryan

item.title: Ring Ends Deal to Link Neighborhood Cameras After Backlash to Super Bowl Ad
item.description: A commercial about a lost dog being reunited with his family ignited concerns that a “Search Party” feature posed privacy risks. Ring parted ways with the tech company Flock Safety.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ring doorbell security camera on the front of a building in New York. The planned integration of those cameras to activate a search function gave rise to criticism after a Super Bowl ad.

item.title: How ICE Is Pushing Tech Companies to Identify Protesters
item.description: The DHS is flooding social media companies with administrative subpoenas to identify accounts that are protesting ICE. Social media companies have pushed back but are largely complying. Our tech reporter, Sheera Frenkel, explains.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel, Christina Thornell, Valentina Caval, Thomas Vollkommer, Jon Hazell and June Kim

item.title: Software? No Way. We’re an A.I. Company Now!
item.description: As their stocks tank, software makers are rebranding themselves as A.I. innovators. Sparkle emojis are everywhere, but some efforts have been more successful than others.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kessler
item.media:credit: Javier Palma

item.title: Can You Rely on A.I. to Translate Love?
item.description: A.I. translation has become a huge industry, but how accurate is it? Our tech reporter, Kashmir Hill, explores its successes and failures through a couple who relies on of A.I. translation to communicate.
item.dc:creator: Kashmir Hill, Gilad Thaler, Kassie Bracken, Jon Miller, Jon Hazell and Joey Sendaydiego

item.title: T.S.A. Workers Brace for Another Shutdown They Didn’t Cause
item.description: As Congress leaves town without funding their department, airport security officers wonder, “How many more times am I going to be able to do this?”
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan and Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: The shutdown is especially hard for T.S.A. employees this time around, because many are just recovering from the financial strain they suffered during last year’s 43-day shutdown.

item.title: Sick Detainees Describe Poor Care at CoreCivic ICE Facilities
item.description: Problems at detention centers operated by CoreCivic extend far beyond recent measles outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Melena Ryzik
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Weinberg for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amalia, a young girl who became dangerously ill at a CoreCivic detention center, with her parents after she was released last week.

item.title: The 2026 Milan Olympics Has Its Eyes on Grana Padano
item.description: Grana Padano cheese is trying to capture some of the international spotlight on Italy, appearing on billboards and social media — and in high-protein muffins for athletes.
item.dc:creator: Kim Severson
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: Grana Padano, which monks began making in the 12th century, is everywhere at the 2026 Olympics.

item.title: How A.I. Salaries Are Causing Couples to Rethink Money in Relationships
item.description: The artificial intelligence frenzy is creating personal fortunes rarely seen in modern technology and changing people’s attitudes about fairness and money in relationships.
item.dc:creator: Kami Rieck
item.media:credit: Ian C. Bates for The New York Times
item.media:description: Akash Samant is a co-founder of Coverflow, an A.I. start-up that serves insurance agencies. He hopes to make enough money from his company going public or being acquired to give his girlfriend the choice to opt out of working.

item.title: How China Built a Chip Industry, and Why It’s Still Not Enough
item.description: More than a decade into Beijing’s push for self sufficiency, Chinese firms are producing fewer, lower-performing chips than their foreign competitors.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation complex in Shanghai. The Chinese government has spent more than $150 billion on its push to make cutting-edge chips at home.

item.title: Homeland Security Demands Social Media Sites Reveal Names Behind Anti-ICE Posts
item.description: The department has sent Google, Meta and other companies hundreds of subpoenas for information on accounts that track or comment on Immigration and Customs Enforcement, officials and tech workers said.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Department of Homeland Security is expanding its efforts to identify Americans who oppose Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

item.title: White House Sees Win After 2 Strong Economic Reports
item.description: Solid jobs data and a soft inflation reading for January are welcome news for President Trump. But the bigger economic picture is less encouraging.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Sydney Ember
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: “President Trump has defeated Joe Biden’s inflation crisis,” a White House spokesman said this week. The bigger economic picture is more uncertain.

item.title: Bessent Pushes Senate on Fed Confirmation Amid Backlash Over Criminal Inquiry
item.description: President Trump’s effort to get Kevin M. Warsh confirmed as the next Federal Reserve chair has been complicated by a criminal investigation into Jerome H. Powell.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The comments by Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent underscore the urgency the Trump administration is feeling as it looks to replace the Federal Reserve chair.

item.title: Trying to Cut Costs? Start With Your Phone, Internet and Streaming Bills.
item.description: It’s cold outside — and a fine time to look over your bills and see where you can save.
item.dc:creator: Ann Carrns

item.title: Crises Everywhere, but the Markets Don’t Seem to Mind
item.description: Stocks have prospered while the world has plunged into disorder, an economist says. “Keep calm and carry on” may be the best investors can do.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Sommer
item.media:credit: Chanelle Nibbelink

item.title: U.S. Inflation Eased at Start of the Year
item.description: The Consumer Price Index fell in January to 2.4 percent from 2.7 percent a month
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: More Epstein Fallout for Goldman Sachs, DP World and Beyond
item.description: The Wall Street giant’s top lawyer, whose ties to Jeffrey Epstein had raised questions at the firm, has resigned. Other corporate leaders are also facing blowback.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Vivienne Walt
item.media:credit: Charles Dharapak/Associated Press
item.media:description: Kathryn Ruemmler, Goldman Sachs’s top in-house lawyer whose ties to Jeffrey Epstein have become a major talking point on Wall Street, has announced her resignation.

item.title: The Hidden Number Driving U.S. Job Growth
item.description: After a year of just 181,000 new jobs, January’s 131,000 increase in the U.S. workforce was surprisingly positive. Ben Casselman, The New York Times’ chief economic correspondent, explains the numbers.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman, Christina Thornell, Christina Shaman, June Kim and Nikolay Nikolov

item.title: Another Government Shutdown? Here’s What Travelers Should Know.
item.description: It was not immediately clear whether passengers would face delays at airport security checkpoints in the coming days if a government shutdown does occur.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root
item.media:credit: Lynne Sladky/Associated Press
item.media:description: Employees of the Transportation Security Administration, which is part of the Department of Homeland Security, must work without pay during a shutdown. It’s still unclear if or when travelers would feel the effects.

item.title: Meta Plans to Add Facial Recognition Technology to Its Smart Glasses
item.description: In an internal memo last year, Meta said the political tumult in the United States would distract critics from the feature’s release.
item.dc:creator: Kashmir Hill, Kalley Huang and Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: Lucia Vazquez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The maker of Meta’s smart glasses said it sold more than seven million pairs last year.

item.title: Christie’s to Auction 3 of Agnes Gund’s Art Jewels
item.description: A Rothko, a Twombly and a Surrealist box with a Medici princess by Joseph Cornell are estimated to sell for $145 million.
item.dc:creator: Julia Halperin

item.title: Conspiracy Theories Only Flourish With More Epstein Evidence
item.description: The dump of millions of documents has fueled a new wave of speculation, A.I.-generated hoaxes and foreign disinformation.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu and Steven Lee Myers
item.media:credit: Gabriella N. Baez for The New York Times
item.media:description: New emails and documents about Jeffrey Epstein, the convicted sex offender who owned Little Saint James Island, above, have spawned a wave of new conspiracy theories and hoaxes.

item.title: Crab Heist Puts Spotlight on Surge of Cargo Thefts
item.description: Stolen food and beverages, which are easier to offload than costly electronics, are driving an overall spike in cargo crimes, truckers, insurers and other experts say.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan

item.title: RFK Jr. Allies Target States to Overturn Vaccine Mandates for Schools
item.description: Proponents of vaccines warn that the efforts will further dismantle the immunization infrastructure and lead to more outbreaks of disease.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: An empty classroom at the high school in Williston, N.D., during an outbreak of measles there last year.

item.title: Amtrak’s Largest Train Revamp in 55 Years Is Coming Soon
item.description: Step inside the sprawling factory in California where the largest fleet replacement in Amtrak’s 55-year history is coming together piece by piece.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root and Ruth Fremson

item.title: Venezuela’s Natural Gas, Not Oil, Might Be a Big Early Prize
item.description: The South American country has natural gas that could be extracted and exported quickly, but U.S. sanctions, which are now being eased, have stymied development.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott and Daniel Wood
item.media:credit: Tony Cenicola/The New York Times
item.media:description: A liquefied natural gas terminal in Trinidad and Tobago, a country that has the infrastructure that Venezuela needs to bring its vast reserves of natural gas to market.

item.title: Iran Turns to Digital Surveillance Tools to Track Down Protesters
item.description: As Iranian authorities restore some online services after crushing antigovernment demonstrations, they are using a technological dragnet to target attendees of the protests.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters blocked a road last month in Tehran. Iran is using facial recognition and phone data to track and detain people involved in political opposition activities.

item.title: Goldman Sachs General Counsel Kathryn Ruemmler Resigns Over Epstein Ties
item.description: Kathryn Ruemmler, a former top Obama administration lawyer, is out at Goldman Sachs after emails showed a friendship with the sex offender Jeffrey Epstein spanning many years.
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland, Maureen Farrell, Lauren Hirsch and Duy Nguyen
item.media:credit: William B. Plowman/NBC
item.media:description: Kathryn Ruemmler, the general counsel at Goldman Sachs, in 2014. She said Thursday that her responsibility “is to put Goldman Sachs’s interests first.”

item.title: El Paso Incident Highlights Gaps in America’s Drone Defense Industry
item.description: The U.S. has spent billions of dollars developing counter-drone technology, but much of it needs more testing in the real world.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Center for a New American Security
item.media:credit: Jose Luis Gonzalez/Reuters
item.media:description: Many flights at El Paso International Airport were canceled on Wednesday, when the Federal Aviation Administration shut down air traffic there for hours.

item.title: Trump’s Actions Test the Fragile World of Air Travel
item.description: Last-minute announcements and abrupt changes by the Trump administration have caused confusion in an already strained U.S. aviation system.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi and Christine Chung
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nearly deserted security checkpoint at El Paso International Airport on Wednesday after the Federal Aviation Administration announced a 10-day ban on flights over the city.

item.title: Flexibility and Rising Costs Are Keeping Mothers at Work
item.description: Labor force participation for women with small children continues to float above prepandemic levels, thanks to flexible work setups — and rising costs.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember
item.media:credit: Rebecca Kiger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kelsey Whitlatch, 28, of Moundsville, W.Va., said she considered not working to focus on her children, ages 5 and 2. But with the rising costs of groceries and utilities, her family needs the second income.

item.title: Americans Are Paying the Bill for Tariffs, Despite Trump’s Claims
item.description: Research from the New York Fed confirms that U.S. companies and consumers are bearing tariff costs, despite the president’s assertions otherwise.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Sydney Ember
item.category: Federal Reserve Bank of New York
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. companies and consumers are paying most of the cost of tariffs, in the form of higher prices.

item.title: Europe Worries Trump Poses Threat to Its Financial and Tech Sovereignty
item.description: European leaders have been compelled to address the possibility of once-remote risks to the financial networks and technology that undergird their economies.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen and Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Nicolas Tucat/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The European Commission’s headquarters in Brussels. The Trump administration’s embrace of cryptocurrency has ratcheted up European concerns about control of the euro.

item.title: Dutch Prosecutors Fine Louis Vuitton Netherlands in Money Laundering Case
item.description: The Dutch subsidiary of the luxury brand agreed to pay a nearly $600,000 settlement in a money laundering and terrorism financing case.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses

item.title: South Korean Court Rules Against Women in LG Inheritance Lawsuit
item.description: The widow and two daughters of LG’s former chairman sought to invalidate an inheritance agreement, claiming they were deceived into forfeiting their rightful inheritance.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Grace Moon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: From left: Koo Yeon-kyung; Kim Young-shik; and Koo Yeon-sue at their home in Itaewon, Seoul, in 2023.

item.title: The Giant Super PACs Fighting Over A.I. Safety
item.description: Anthropic is pouring millions of dollars into a political action committee that will most likely face off against OpenAI.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Ian Mount
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dario Amodei, the C.E.O. of Anthropic, has supported tighter regulation around artificial intelligence.

item.title: States Say No Thanks to Trump Tax Cuts, Drawing Republican Fire
item.description: State income taxes often reflect federal policies, but Washington, D.C. and some states have taken steps to keep the latest Republican changes out of their tax codes.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Muriel Bowser of Washington and other local officials warned that a sudden change to the city’s tax code would upend filing season in the capital.

item.title: Ford Will Make a Play for a Different Battery Market
item.description: The company, long focused on cars and trucks, plans to begin manufacturing large batteries used by utilities, data centers, other businesses and homeowners.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ford’s closed battery plant in Glendale, Ky., which it plans to revamp to produce large storage batteries.
